Blackburn et al.
24 suggested a unified framework for biological invasions that combines aspects of both plant and animal ecology and focuses on human-mediated invasions. This framework describes the progressive stages of an invasion from transportation to fully invasive, including specific barriers for each stage (Table 1). A nonindigenous species only progresses through successive stages of invasion when it possesses barrier-specific functional traits
11 . For example, successful invasive species often have traits such as wide environmental and climatic tolerances, a generalist diet, high reproductive potential and good dispersal ability
25, 26 . By identifying species with traits associated with high invasive potential, invasions with negative impacts can be predicted and prevented more effectively
27 .
